talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
So the issue here is that there are two different ways (two main ways, anyway) that AI can infringe: the input used for training can be infringing, or the output can be.

Right now, I'm talking about the input - can you just copy stuff into the AI and call it "reading."

talk.author: did:plc:gh254rimuujtpiuvrsk4vgyo
talk.utter:
Under the law, my (NAL) opinion is, you can. 

You DO need legal rights to the material, so no scraping illegal book 'libraries'. But you can check out digital books from a library, or scrape public web content that doesn't explicitly prohibit that use.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter:
It's not the kind of infringement likely to be a crime. 

But the use is the important factor - because an unlicensed copy is infringement unless the use is excused (eg by fair use). Generally, indexing to provide information about things is fair use. Uses that compete with originals usually isn't.

talk.author: did:plc:gh254rimuujtpiuvrsk4vgyo
talk.utter:
My wife is reminding me I have to go get groceries, which takes precedence.

I think you're correct in that it's the OUTPUT that's at issue, legally AND morally. And another aspect of it is *scale*. Even if the process is not problematic by hand, it can become so when it's done a million times.

talk.author: did:plc:mivey63nzylfflvmmjoqcf6u
talk.utter: Copying into memory - even just into RAM - is still a copy. That's black-letter law. Your right to make that copy is limited to the rights provided by the license. So, probably it doesn't matter whether it's bought or checked-out, because in either case the use is outside the scope of the license.
